articles.headline: RIM Suffers as Profit Falls 58.7%
articles.snippet: RIM blamed sagging sales of its aging line of smartphones for much of its discouraging financial news.
articles.abstract: RIM blamed sagging sales of its aging line of smartphones for much of its discouraging financial news.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The BlackBerry maker Research in Motion delivered more grim financial news on Thursday that caused some analysts to question the future of RIM, the company that created and once dominated the smartphone market.

articles.headline: Where Banks Proliferate, So Do Rules
articles.snippet: Regulators in the United States, Britain and Switzerland seem to be moving toward tougher rules on banks than much of continental Europe is, but there are still weaknesses to be addressed.
articles.abstract: Regulators in the United States, Britain and Switzerland seem to be moving toward tougher rules on banks than much of continental Europe is, but there are still weaknesses to be addressed.
articles.lead_paragraph: The more banks a country has, the less political power they have.

articles.headline: Long-Term Stock Plans Help to Avoid Impulsive Moves
articles.snippet: Things to consider in assessing whether your money is invested in a way that you can handle for the long haul.
articles.abstract: Things to consider in assessing whether your money is invested in a way that you can handle for the long haul.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUST as you caught your breath after the stock market mayhem of 2008 and 2009, it has become increasingly clear that this ride isn’t over just yet.

articles.headline: China Consolidates Grip on Rare Earths
articles.snippet: By closing or nationalizing dozens of the producers of rare earth metals, which are used in energy-efficient bulbs, China is crimping the global supply.
articles.abstract: By closing or nationalizing dozens of the producers of rare earth metals, which are used in energy-efficient bulbs, China is crimping the global supply.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In the name of fighting pollution, China has sent the price of compact fluorescent light bulbs soaring in the United States.

articles.headline: The Company You Keep
articles.snippet: Many older Americans are planning their retirements in more detail, from their new communities to the hometown friends they want to bring with them.
articles.abstract: Many older Americans are planning their retirements in more detail, from their new communities to the hometown friends they want to bring with them.
articles.lead_paragraph: ONE of the biggest challenges of relocating after retirement is making new acquaintances.

articles.headline: Metal Hips Failing Fast, Report Says
articles.snippet: A British registry found that all-metal artificial hips failed at a significantly higher rate than those made from other materials.
articles.abstract: A British registry found that all-metal artificial hips failed at a significantly higher rate than those made from other materials.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a troubling development for people with all-metal artificial hips, a registry that tracks orthopedic implants in Britain reported on Thursday that the failure rate of the devices was increasing.

articles.headline: Hedge Fund Chief Takes Major Role in Philanthropy
articles.snippet: Jim Steyer has joined with his brother to build the Center for the Next Generation, a nonprofit group formed to participate in major public policy debates.
articles.abstract: Jim Steyer has joined with his brother to build the Center for the Next Generation, a nonprofit group formed to participate in major public policy debates.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Until last year, Tom Steyer was just another billionaire hedge fund manager intent on keeping a low profile.

articles.headline: Arrest of UBS Trader Rattles Banks in Europe
articles.snippet: A rogue trading case at UBS, with its $2 billion in losses, has raised questions about the oversight of banks in Europe.
articles.abstract: A rogue trading case at UBS, with its $2 billion in losses, has raised questions about the oversight of banks in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kweku Adoboli traveled from Ghana to Israel to a Quaker boarding school before attending a leading university in Nottingham, England. With his education pedigree, he landed a coveted job at UBS, the giant Swiss bank, right after graduation.
articles.byline: By Julia Werdigier and Ben Protess

articles.headline: At White House, Weighing Limits of Terror Fight
articles.snippet: At issue is how much latitude the United States has to kill militants in Yemen and Somalia, a question that could define the limits of the war against Al Qaeda and its allies.
articles.abstract: At issue is how much latitude the United States has to kill militants in Yemen and Somalia, a question that could define the limits of the war against Al Qaeda and its allies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s legal team is split over how much latitude the United States has to kill Islamist militants in Yemen and Somalia, a question that could define the limits of the war against Al Qaeda and its allies, according to administration and Congressional officials.

articles.headline: Bahrain Boils Under the Lid of Repression
articles.snippet: Bahrain has become the cornerstone of a counterrevolution to stanch change in the Middle East, but many fear the violence will beget more violence.
articles.abstract: Bahrain has become the cornerstone of a counterrevolution to stanch change in the Middle East, but many fear the violence will beget more violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANAMA, Bahrain — The battle began soon after sundown. And for the next six hours, in air heavy with heat and tear gas, phalanxes of police officers in helmets battled scores of youths in ski masks, as customers at a Costa Coffee not far away sat like spectators.

articles.headline: Post-Grunge, Seattle Rocks On
articles.snippet: Twenty years after the release of Nirvana’s “Nevermind,” a new exhibition, a film and a tribute concert planned for the anniversary make it clear how different things are in Seattle.
articles.abstract: Twenty years after the release of Nirvana’s “Nevermind,” a new exhibition, a film and a tribute concert planned for the anniversary make it clear how different things are in Seattle.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Three months before he killed himself, Kurt Cobain spoke of his band’s breakthrough single at a concert here that turned out to be one of Nirvana’s final performances in the United States.
articles.byline: By William Yardley and Sean Patrick Farrell

articles.headline: Libya Counts More Martyrs Than Bodies
articles.snippet: The death toll from the Libyan uprising has become a politically delicate issue, with some new government officials refusing to release hard statistics on casualties.
articles.abstract: The death toll from the Libyan uprising has become a politically delicate issue, with some new government officials refusing to release hard statistics on casualties.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Where are all the dead?

articles.headline: Advice on Debt? Europe Suggests U.S. Can Keep It
articles.snippet: The United States has long been considered a financial adviser to the rest of the world — until now.
articles.abstract: The United States has long been considered a financial adviser to the rest of the world — until now.
articles.lead_paragraph: WROCLAW, Poland — The United States has long been considered a financial adviser to the rest of the world. But these days, American officials come carrying baggage.
articles.byline: By Stephen Castle and Louise Story
